chatgpt_double_star.new_statement: Laws on abortion should be built around two goals most people share: preventing avoidable suffering and treating both pregnancy and parenthood with moral seriousness. That means guaranteeing prompt, confidential, evidence-based care—including unambiguous exceptions for threats to life or serious health and for cases of rape, incest, or fatal fetal conditions—while keeping any later limits clear, medically workable, and free of vague standards that chill care. Whatever boundaries are set, they should be paired with real prevention and support—contraception access, accurate education, prenatal/postpartum care, and economic help—so fewer people face the decision under desperation.

chatgpt_double_star_rankings.new_statement: Abortion laws should be guided by compassion and harm reduction in a pluralistic society: protect the pregnant person’s health, dignity, privacy, and timely access to evidence-based care while acknowledging that many assign moral value to developing life. Policy should keep most decisions in the patient–clinician relationship, set any limits with clear, medically workable standards, and include explicit exceptions for life-threatening or serious health risks and other rare, traumatic circumstances so clinicians can act without fear. The broadest common ground is pairing the legal framework with strong prevention and support—contraception and accurate education, plus prenatal/postpartum care and practical resources for parenting and adoption—so fewer people face the decision in crisis.

chatgpt_double_star_personas.new_statement: Abortion laws should be guided by compassion, human dignity, and practical harm reduction—recognizing sincere moral disagreement while ensuring no one is denied timely, evidence-based care when pregnancy becomes dangerous or traumatic. Policy should keep most decisions in the patient–clinician relationship, set any limits with clear, medically workable standards and explicit exceptions for threats to life or serious health, and avoid criminalizing patients or clinicians acting in good faith. Common ground is strongest when the law is paired with real prevention and support—accessible contraception and accurate education, plus prenatal/postpartum care, paid leave/childcare, and adoption and economic resources—so fewer people face the decision in crisis.
